"Participants were advised to undertake the exercise programme a minimum of twice a week and to complete their online exercise diary which was seen remotely by the physiotherapist." - This quote suggests that participants were encouraged to adhere to the exercise program, but there were no strict measures or exclusions based on adherence. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Follow-up:
1. "Outcome measures were recorded at baseline and at the end of the intervention period (week 13)." - This quote indicates that the follow-up in the trial was similar to what would be done in usual care, with measurements taken at baseline and at the end of the intervention period. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary outcome:
1. "For the primary outcome measure, the timed 25ft walk, the gait speed increased in the intervention group compared to the control group but this was not statistically significant (P=0.170)." - This quote suggests that the primary outcome measure was relevant to the participants, as it assessed their gait speed. However, the lack of statistical significance may indicate that the outcome measure was not sensitive enough to detect a difference between the intervention and control groups. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

However, there is no information provided about the handling of missing data or the inclusion of ineligible post-randomization participants. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Patients were randomised in a ratio 2:1 to an intervention group (133) or a control group (68)." [quote 1]
2. "To be eligible, all patients screened for study participation had to be affected by clinically definite multiple sclerosis and live in the Rome service area." [quote 2]
3. "Patients could be admitted to the scheme only if they agreed to be randomised." [quote 3]

The full text provides information on the eligibility criteria for the trial. Patients had to have clinically definite multiple sclerosis and live in the Rome service area. The randomization process was described, indicating that patients had to agree to be randomized. Based on this information, the trial appears to have a pragmatic approach to eligibility. 

Score: [4]

Recruitment:
1. "Patients were recruited from the multiple sclerosis centre of the neurological department of La Sapienza University, or from other institutional centres for multiple sclerosis in Rome." [quote 4]
2. "The majority of refusers (n = 62) were young, fully ambulant, and employed. They were uncertain that home based management could be adopted in their situations." [quote 5]
3. "Patients could be admitted to the scheme only if they agreed to be randomised." [quote 3]

The full text mentions that patients were recruited from multiple sclerosis centers in Rome. It also provides information on the reasons for refusal to participate, indicating that some patients were uncertain about home-based management. However, there is no information on the recruitment methods used or any additional efforts made to recruit participants. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the level of effort in recruitment.

Score: [NA]

Setting:
1. "The study was conducted in Rome." [quote 6]
2. "Patients were recruited from the multiple sclerosis centre of the neurological department of La Sapienza University, or from other institutional centres for multiple sclerosis in Rome." [quote 4]

The full text indicates that the study was conducted in Rome and patients were recruited from multiple sclerosis centers in Rome. However, there is no information on the specific settings where the intervention and control groups received care. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the difference in setting between the trial and usual care.

Score: [NA]

Organisation:
1. "The multidisciplinary team collaborated with the patient, physician, and caregiver in designing individualised clinical care and in coordinating home services as appropriate for the individual patient." [quote 7]
2. "The type of care was more than is normally available in the community through National Health Service care." [quote 7]

The full text describes the involvement of a multidisciplinary team in designing individualized clinical care and coordinating home services. It also mentions that the type of care provided was more than what is normally available through the National Health Service. Based on this information, it can be inferred that the trial involved additional resources and expertise compared to usual care.

Score: [2]

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "Based on individual needs, patients randomised to home based care were followed through home visits and telephone follow up." [quote 7]
2. "The multidisciplinary team collaborated with the patient, physician, and caregiver in designing individualised clinical care and in coordinating home services as appropriate for the individual patient." [quote 7]

The full text indicates that the home-based care intervention was tailored to individual needs and involved home visits and telephone follow-up. The involvement of a multidisciplinary team in designing individualized care further suggests flexibility in the delivery of the intervention. Therefore, the trial appears to have a pragmatic approach to flexibility in delivery.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):
1. "Patients randomised to routine hospital care were followed as usual in their multiple sclerosis referral centres." [quote 7]
2. "A brief monitoring phone call once a month was used to obtain information about the patient’s medical visits and hospital admissions in the previous month." [quote 7]

The full text indicates that patients in the control group received routine hospital care and were followed as usual in multiple sclerosis referral centers. There is no mention of specific measures to improve adherence or exclusion based on adherence. Therefore, it can be inferred that there was no additional emphasis on adherence in the trial.

Score: [5]

Follow-up:
1. "At the end of a one year follow up period, all patients underwent the same comprehensive interview as at baseline." [quote 7]

The full text mentions a one-year follow-up period and indicates that all patients underwent the same comprehensive interview at the end of the follow-up. However, there is no information on the intensity of measurement or the frequency of follow-up visits. Therefore, it is difficult to assess the difference in follow-up intensity between the trial and usual care.

Score: [NA]

Primary outcome:
1. "They were assessed at baseline and one year after randomisation with validated measures of physical and psychological impairment and quality of life (SF-36 health survey)." [quote 7]
2. "There were no differences in functional status between the home based care group and the hospital group." [quote 8]

The full text mentions that the primary outcome measures included physical and psychological impairment and quality of life. It also reports that there were no differences in functional status between the home-based care group and the hospital group. Based on this information, it can be inferred that the trial's primary outcome was relevant to participants.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
1. "Baseline data for intervention and control groups were compared using a χ2 test for categorical variables, a t test for normally distributed continuous variables, and the Wilcoxon rank-sum test for abnormally distributed variables." [quote 9]
2. "For each scale of the SF-36 and separately for the case and control group, we adopted a regression model in which score changes at the end of the follow up period were adjusted for the baseline values." [quote 9]

The full text describes the statistical methods used for the primary analysis, including comparisons of baseline data and regression models to adjust for baseline values. It indicates that all available data were included in the analysis. Therefore, the trial appears to have a pragmatic approach to the primary analysis.

Score: [5]

Based on this information, it can be inferred that the trial's primary outcome was relevant to participants.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Participants required to have a clinical diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis, persistent foot drop (lasting a minimum of three months) observed during a 5-minute walk test, stable disease (no change in the Extended Disability Status Score12 or relapse in previous three months), 5° of passive dorsiflexion and tolerance of functional electrical stimulation. Participants were excluded if they had previously used functional electrical stimulation or an ankle-foot orthosis for foot drop, moderate to severe cognitive impairment (scored < 26, Montreal Cognitive Assessment),13 foot drop due to other disorders, other conditions significantly affecting gait, contraindications to functional electrical stimulation, marked proximal weakness, plantar flexor spasticity, stance phase instability or severe lower limb/trunk ataxia affecting gait." [NA]
2. "Eighty-five participants met the criteria for inclusion and consented to participate in the study between September 2014 and January 2017." [NA]

Recruitment:
1. "Potential participants known to Multiple Sclerosis healthcare practitioners working across seven outpatient centres in Scotland – Ayrshire & Arran, Greater Glasgow & Clyde, Dumfries and Galloway, Lanarkshire, Lothian, Fife and Tayside – were informed of the study and issued with a participant information sheet. Potential participants contacted the researchers if they were interested in participating." [NA]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Participants were non-institutionalized adults (age ⩾ 18 years) with severe MS and their primary carers. Other patient inclusion criteria were primary or secondary progressive MS,1,13 Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score ⩾ 8.0,14 complex symptoms,15 and ⩾2 unmet care needs.16 The carer (a family member, relative, or friend of the patient) was his or her next of kin and was designated by the patient except for patients with severe cognitive compromise." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets> The eligibility criteria for this trial are fairly pragmatic, as they include a broad range of patients with severe MS and their primary carers. However, the exclusion of patients with severe cognitive compromise may limit the generalizability of the results to this population.

Recruitment:
1. "Participants were non-institutionalized adults (age ⩾ 18 years) with severe MS and their primary carers." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets> The recruitment strategy for this trial appears to be fairly pragmatic, as it targets non-institutionalized adults with severe MS and their primary carers. However, the full text does not provide specific details about the recruitment process, such as whether participants were recruited from multiple sites or how they were identified and approached.

Setting:
1. "In this randomized, examiner-blind, controlled study, we recruited patients from three Italian centers." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [3]</moved-squared-brackets> The trial was conducted at three Italian centers, which suggests that the setting may be somewhat explanatory. However, without further information about the characteristics of these centers and how they compare to usual care settings, it is difficult to make a definitive assessment.

Organization:
1. "Based on the principles of PC,17 each center had a HPA team consisting of a physician (neurologist or physiatrist), a nurse (case manager and team leader), a psychologist, and a social worker." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets> The organization of care delivery in the intervention arm of the trial appears to be fairly pragmatic, as it involves a multi-professional team that is consistent with usual care for palliative care. However, the full text does not provide specific details about any additional resources, provider expertise, or changes in care delivery that may be different from usual care.

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "After a comprehensive assessment of the dyad needs based on direct observation and on visit 1 information (available via the eCRF), the HPA team defined the contents of the intervention, involving the dyad and the patient caring physician (the intervention was not intended to replace existing services)." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets> The flexibility in how the intervention is delivered appears to be fairly pragmatic, as it is based on a comprehensive assessment of the dyad's needs and involves collaboration with the patient's physician. However, the full text does not provide specific details about any strict protocols or restrictions on how the intervention is delivered.

Flexibility (adherence):
1. "All team activities were recorded in the PeNSAMI patient study record, which was kept at the patient’s home and available to all HPs/caregivers." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets> The flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention appears to be very pragmatic, as there are no specific requirements or measures to improve adherence mentioned in the full text.

Follow-up:
1. "A blind examiner assessed dyads at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets> The intensity of measurement and follow-up of participants in the trial appears to be fairly pragmatic, as it involves assessments at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. However, the full text does not provide specific details about the frequency or duration of these assessments compared to usual care.

Primary outcome:
1. "Primary outcome measures were Palliative care Outcome Scale-Symptoms-MS (POS-S-MS) and Schedule for the Evaluation of Individual Quality of Life-Direct Weighting (SEIQoL-DW, not assessed in severely cognitively compromised patients)." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets> The primary outcome measures for this trial appear to be fairly pragmatic, as they include patient-reported outcomes that are relevant to participants with severe MS. However, the exclusion of severely cognitively compromised patients from the SEIQoL-DW assessment may limit the generalizability of the results to this population.

Primary analysis:
1. "All randomly assigned patients were included in the main intention-to-treat analysis, provided that at least one contact with the team occurred (HPA group)." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets> The primary analysis of the trial appears to be very pragmatic, as it includes all randomly assigned patients in the intention-to-treat analysis, regardless of their level of adherence to the intervention.

Overall, the trial appears to have a fairly pragmatic design, with some domains leaning more towards the explanatory end of the spectrum. The eligibility criteria, recruitment strategy, and primary outcome measures are all fairly pragmatic, while the setting, organization of care delivery, and flexibility in delivery are somewhat explanatory. The flexibility in adherence and the primary analysis are very pragmatic.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "The main inclusion criteria were: (1) clinically definite MS diagnosis, (2) fatigue impacting on daily life (Fatigue Severity Scale total score >4)16 and (3) ambulatory. The main exclusion criteria were: (1) having taken part in a fatigue programme in the last year, (2) cognitive impairments, (3) a relapse in the previous 3 months or (4) having started treatment with disease modifying or antidepressant drugs within the previous 3 months." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Recruitment:
1. "Participants were recruited in three UK centres (Poole, Bristol, Southampton/Portsmouth) from primary or secondary care, or via MS Society newsletters/websites." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Setting:
1. "FACETS was delivered in hotel meeting-room facilities, with the exception of one centre, where it was held in a rehabilitation hospital." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [3]</moved-squared-brackets>

Organisation:
1. "Facilitators were all qualified to a senior/advanced level (in the UK minimum of a Band 7 on the NHS Agenda for Change (AfC) grading structure).17 Facilitators were trained to deliver the intervention at 1-day workshops and psychological advice and debriefing were available for facilitators throughout the trial." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "The manualised group-based FACETS programme is described elsewhere13 and is based upon a conceptual framework integrating elements from cognitive behavioural, social-cognitive, energy effectiveness, self-management and self-efficacy theories." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (adherence):
1. "Participants receiving the intervention continued to have access to services available as part of their usual local care." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Follow-up:
1. "For those allocated to the FACETS arm, outcomes were measured 1 week (baseline) before the start of FACETS and 1 month (follow-up 1) and 4 months (follow-up 2) after the final session." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary outcome:
1. "There were statistically significantly greater improvements in fatigue self-efficacy in the FACETS arm at follow-up 1 and 2 compared with the CLP arm." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary analysis:
1. "The main analysis was intention-to-treat but we also conducted a ‘per protocol’ analysis (excluding participants who attended fewer than four FACETS sessions)." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Inclusion criteria for the study included (1) a diagnosis of MS, (2) not currently engaged in rehabilitation, therapy or PA program and able to undertake PA without risk-factors (3) aged between 18 and 65 (4) able to give informed consent and to understand French." <added-score-prefix>Score: [NA]</added-score-prefix>
2. "We excluded those who were receiving drug treatment for fatigue started less than three months ago or acute hospital or nursing home, those who were having psychiatric disorders." <added-score-prefix>Score: [NA]</added-score-prefix>

Recruitment:
1. "Participants were recruited from two hospitals in the Parisian region, in France receiving outpatient services for MS at a regional medical center." <added-score-prefix>Score: [4]</added-score-prefix>
2. "All participants provided written informed consent and underwent a neurological exam by two physicians who provided EDSS scores considered as a clinical measure of disability." <added-score-prefix>Score: [4]</added-score-prefix>

Setting:
1. "This study is a randomized controlled pilot trial of a brief intervention combining Physical activity, Mindfulness training and Implementation intention to decrease fatigue and improve mobility among people with MS." <added-score-prefix>Score: [3]</added-score-prefix>

Organisation:
1. "The PA program was manualized and available as a booklet. This program initiated after the primary actimetry measurement and maintained for 8 consecutive weeks with a frequency of 2 h weekly." <added-score-prefix>Score: [4]</added-score-prefix>
2. "Mindfulness practice took place individually at home without any assistance six times per week." <added-score-prefix>Score: [4]</added-score-prefix>

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "Mindfulness practice took place individually at home six times per week, without any assistance." <added-score-prefix>Score: [4]</added-score-prefix>

1. "Participants were asked to listen to the prerecorded sessions and to follow the instructions." <added-score-prefix>Score: [5]</added-score-prefix>

Follow-up:
1. "The primary outcomes, fatigue, mobility, and quality of life, were examined at baseline prior to randomization, and then 8-weeks after the intervention." <added-score-prefix>Score: [5]</added-score-prefix>

Primary outcome:
1. "The primary outcomes, fatigue, mobility, and quality of life, were examined at baseline prior to randomization, and then 8-weeks after the intervention." <added-score-prefix>Score: [5]</added-score-prefix>

Primary analysis:

llm_message:
Eligibility:
- "20 subjects with relapsing–remitting or progressive MS, 26–50 years of age, with EDSS ≤ 6 and EDSS pyramidal functions score (EDSSpyr) > 2 were enrolled in a randomized prospective study." [1]
- "Our sample size was rather small and each group was heterogeneous in the type of MS while there were no significant differences in the type of MS between the two groups." [4]
- "Heterogeneity could be avoided only in larger population than Slovenian, because our inclusion criteria considering EDSS and living nearby the exercising facilities (radius of approximately 40 km) excluded a great deal of Slovenian patients with MS." [4]

The full text provides information on the eligibility criteria for the trial, including the type of MS, age range, and EDSS scores. However, the small sample size and lack of diversity in the type of MS limit the generalizability of the findings. Based on the available information, the trial can be considered moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

Recruitment:
- "20 patients with relapsing–remitting MS, primary progressive MS or secondary progressive MS, aged 26–50 years, with an EDSS not more than 6 and EDSS pyramidal functions score (EDSSpyr) more than 2 were included in the prospective study." [2]
- "Participants were randomized into SC or yoga group." [2]
- "We evaluated the progression of disease, spasticity, cognitive function, mood and fatigue before and after both programs." [2]

The full text does not provide specific details on the recruitment process, such as how participants were identified or approached to participate in the trial. However, it does mention that participants were randomized into the SC or yoga group, indicating a systematic approach to recruitment. Based on the available information, the trial can be considered moderately pragmatic.

Score: [3]

Setting:
- "SC took place in the Training, Occupation and Care Centre under the supervision of two SC instructors with a Slovenian Sports Climbing Committee License." [2]
- "Hatha yoga took place in the facilities of Institute of Rehabilitation, Republic of Slovenia." [2]

The full text provides information on the specific settings where the SC and yoga interventions took place. However, it does not provide information on how these settings compare to usual care settings. Based on the available information, the trial can be considered moderately explanatory.

Score: [3]

Organisation:
- "The climbing wall with an inclination of 90° and the height of 5 m was adjusted for patients with physical disabilities by adding numerous and bigger holds." [2]
- "All patients were belayed with the “top rope” system, which provided a safe climbing opportunity with the possibility to rest in the wall at any point." [2]
- "The program was adjusted for MS patients and was held by a MS specialist nurse who is a yoga instructor with a license for patients with physical disabilities." [2]

The full text provides information on the adjustments made to the climbing wall and the qualifications of the yoga instructor. These adjustments and qualifications suggest that the trial required additional resources and expertise beyond usual care. Based on the available information, the trial can be considered moderately explanatory.

Score: [3]

- "Heterogeneity could be avoided only in larger population than Slovenian, because our inclusion criteria considering EDSS and living nearby the exercising facilities (radius of approximately 40 km) excluded a great deal of Slovenian patients with MS." [4]

The full text provides information on the eligibility criteria for the trial, including the type of MS, age range, and EDSS scores. However, the small sample size and lack of diversity in the type of MS limit the generalizability of the findings. Based on the available information, the trial can be considered moderately pragmatic.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
- "MS patients older than 18 years who had a confirmed MS with spasticity of the lower limbs and an Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) between 4 and 6.5 were eligible for inclusion." [1]
- "Patients who had received hippotherapy within the last 12 months, a body weight over 90 kg, no balance while sitting, and acute exacerbation during the 4-week period before start of the therapy were excluded." [1]
- "A planned start of treatment with new anti-spastic drugs or other medications that may have an influence on the assessed outcomes also resulted in exclusion." [1]

The eligibility criteria for this trial appear to be relatively pragmatic. The inclusion criteria are specific to MS patients with spasticity of the lower limbs and an EDSS score between 4 and 6.5. The exclusion criteria are reasonable and do not appear to be overly restrictive. Overall, the trial seems to have a pragmatic approach to participant eligibility.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:
- "A total of 70 adults with MS were recruited in five German centers and randomly allocated to the intervention group (12 weeks of hippotherapy) or the control group." [1]

The recruitment process is not described in detail in the full text. However, it is mentioned that 70 adults with MS were recruited in five German centers. The recruitment process does not appear to involve any additional efforts beyond what would be used in usual care. Therefore, it can be considered relatively pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Setting:
- "The study was conducted at five sites in Germany, all of which have hippotherapy experience as stipulated by the rules of the German Consortium for Therapeutic Riding." [1]

The trial was conducted at five sites in Germany. While the specific settings are not described in detail, it is mentioned that all sites have hippotherapy experience as stipulated by the rules of the German Consortium for Therapeutic Riding. This suggests that the trial was conducted in settings that are familiar with and capable of providing hippotherapy. Therefore, the trial can be considered relatively explanatory.

Score: [2]

Organisation:
- "Patients in the control group continued their previous therapy. Over the study period, symptomatic drug treatment, immunotherapy, and physiotherapy were kept unchanged in both groups." [1]

The organization of care delivery in the intervention arm of the trial appears to be similar to usual care. Patients in the control group continued their previous therapy, and symptomatic drug treatment, immunotherapy, and physiotherapy were kept unchanged in both groups. There is no indication that the trial required additional resources or staff levels beyond what is available in usual care. Therefore, the trial can be considered relatively pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
- "Patients of the intervention group received hippotherapy (as defined by the regulations for hippotherapy of the Deutsches Kuratorium für Therapeutisches Reiten e.V. (DKThR)) once a week for 12 weeks as an add-on therapy to their standard care, which remained unchanged." [1]

The intervention in the trial involved hippotherapy once a week for 12 weeks as an add-on therapy to standard care. The description does not indicate any strict protocol, monitoring, or measures to improve compliance. The intervention appears to have a level of flexibility that is similar to what would be expected in usual care. Therefore, the trial can be considered relatively pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):
- This domain is not applicable to this trial as there is no compliance issue after consent has been given.

Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
- "Examinations and questionnaires were completed prior to the first hippotherapy session (baseline), after 6–7 weeks (interim assessment) and after 12 weeks (final assessment)." [1]

The follow-up in the trial involved assessments at baseline, after 6-7 weeks, and after 12 weeks. The frequency and timing of the assessments appear to be similar to what would be expected in usual care. Therefore, the trial can be considered relatively pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
- "Primary outcome was the change in the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) after 12 weeks." [1]

The primary outcome of the trial is the change in the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) after 12 weeks. The BBS is a relevant outcome measure for MS patients and is of obvious importance to participants. Therefore, the trial can be considered relatively pragmatic.

Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
- "Analyses were based on the modified intention-to-treat set (modified ITT). This set encompasses all randomized patients with valid baseline assessment." [1]

The primary analysis of the trial was based on the modified intention-to-treat set, which includes all randomized patients with valid baseline assessment. This approach is consistent with a pragmatic trial design that aims to include all available data in the analysis. Therefore, the trial can be considered relatively pragmatic.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
- "Participants: One hundred and fourteen people with progressive neurological conditions recruited from general practices in Nottingham, including 53 with Parkinson's disease and 45 with multiple sclerosis" [1]
- "Participants eligible for inclusion were adults aged over 15 years with one of the following possible recorded diagnoses: MS, PD and other causes of progressive parkinsonism, motor neurone disease, Huntington's disease and other degenerative disorders affecting the central nervous system, muscles or peripheral nerves." [2]

The full text provides clear information about the eligibility criteria for the trial. It states that participants were adults with specific progressive neurological conditions. The inclusion criteria are well-defined and specific, allowing for a clear understanding of the target population. Therefore, the trial can be considered pragmatic in terms of eligibility.

Score: [5]

Recruitment:
- "From July 1998 we approached the 177 GPs based within the City of Nottingham boundaries (population 282000). Participants eligible for inclusion were adults aged over 15 years with one of the following possible recorded diagnoses: MS, PD and other causes of progressive parkinsonism, motor neurone disease, Huntington's disease and other degenerative disorders affecting the central nervous system, muscles or peripheral nerves." [2]

The full text does not provide specific information about the recruitment process used in the trial. It mentions that the researchers approached general practitioners in Nottingham, but it does not provide details about the methods used to recruit participants. Without this information, it is difficult to assess the level of effort made to recruit participants. 

Score: [NA]

Setting:
- "Setting: Participants' homes in the City of Nottingham." [1]

The full text clearly states that the trial took place in participants' homes in the City of Nottingham. This suggests that the setting of the trial closely resembles the usual care setting for individuals with progressive neurological conditions. Therefore, the trial can be considered pragmatic in terms of setting.

Score: [5]

Organisation:
- "The panel received a written report on each participant prior to meeting, and made suggestions centred on each individual's stated priorities, taking account of risks of falls and sores. Suggested actions ranged from minor changes in the home environment to self-referrals to locally available services." [2]

The full text provides information about the organization of care delivery in the intervention arm of the trial. It mentions that an expert panel reviewed baseline data for each participant and made suggestions for actions to promote well-being. These actions ranged from minor changes to self-referrals to services. This suggests that the trial involved additional resources and expertise beyond usual care. 

Score: [3]

This suggests that there was some flexibility in how the intervention was delivered, as it was personalized to each participant. However, the text does not provide specific details about the level of flexibility or any restrictions on the delivery of the intervention.

Score: [4]

The full text does not provide specific information about the flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention. This suggests that there may have been some flexibility in how participants were able to adhere to the intervention.

The full text mentions that participants were assessed at baseline and 12 months later. Therefore, the trial can be considered pragmatic in terms of follow-up.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Inclusion criteria were the following: diagnosis of MS made by a neurologist, able to walk 10 meters with or without an aid within 2 minutes, no relapse of their MS in the past 4 weeks, and no other neurological or orthopedic condition that would affect their function." [1]
2. "Eligible participants were excluded from the study if they were already engaged in a formal exercise program lasting >30 minutes twice per week, experienced an exacerbation within the past 4 weeks, had their MS immunomodulation medications altered in the previous 4 weeks or during the trial period, or declined to be randomly allocated." [1]

The eligibility criteria for this trial appear to be relatively pragmatic. The inclusion criteria are straightforward and relevant to the target population of people with MS. The exclusion criteria are also reasonable and aim to exclude individuals who may have confounding factors that could affect the outcomes of the trial. Overall, the trial seems to have a pragmatic approach to participant eligibility.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:
1. "Community dwelling people with MS were recruited through the Multiple Sclerosis Society of New South Wales and South Australia." [1]

The recruitment strategy for this trial involved recruiting participants through the Multiple Sclerosis Society, which suggests that efforts were made to engage with the target population. However, the full text does not provide any additional information about the recruitment process, such as whether targeted invitation letters or other forms of advertising were used. Without this information, it is difficult to fully assess the recruitment domain.

Score: [NA]

Setting:
1. "The group program was conducted at a local community center and included four to six participants per class." [1]
2. "Home exercise participants were provided with one center-based physiotherapist-led session at the commencement of the intervention period for training, and telephone support by a physiotherapist to discuss their program every 2 weeks." [1]

The trial involved both a center-based group program and a home-based individual program. The center-based program was conducted at a local community center, which suggests that the setting was similar to usual care. The home-based program allowed participants to exercise in their own homes, which may be different from usual care but could also be considered pragmatic as it provides flexibility and accessibility.

Score: [4]

Organisation:
1. "The group program was conducted at a local community center and included four to six participants per class. Groups were led by a physiotherapist employed by the Multiple Sclerosis Society who received training to ensure a standard approach to intervention, intensity, and progression." [1]
2. "Home exercise participants were provided with one center-based physiotherapist-led session at the commencement of the intervention period for training, and telephone support by a physiotherapist to discuss their program every 2 weeks." [1]

The trial employed physiotherapists to lead both the center-based group program and the home-based individual program. The physiotherapists received training to ensure a standard approach to intervention, intensity, and progression. This suggests that the trial made efforts to provide similar resources and expertise to both intervention arms, which aligns with a pragmatic approach.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "The exercise program for both groups included two, 60-minute sessions per week, held at least 2 days apart for 8 weeks." [1]
2. "In both group and home exercise sessions, participants completed eight, 6-minute exercises/stations per session plus a 5-minute warm up and cool down." [1]

The exercise program in both the center-based group and home-based individual programs had a set schedule of two sessions per week for 8 weeks. The exercises were standardized and participants completed the same number of exercises/stations per session. This suggests that there was limited flexibility in how the intervention was delivered, which leans towards an explanatory approach.

The follow-up assessments were conducted at a local community center, which suggests that the intensity of measurement and follow-up was similar to usual care. However, the full text does not provide information about the frequency or duration of the follow-up assessments, which limits a comprehensive assessment of this domain.

There is no indication that the trial used a surrogate or physiological outcome that is not available in usual care. Therefore, the trial appears to have a pragmatic approach to the primary outcome.

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Male fans of two ice hockey teams (35–65 yr; body mass index ≥28 kg·m−2) located in Ontario (Canada) were randomized to intervention (Hockey FIT) or comparator (wait-list control)." [1]
2. "Eligible participants were male 35–65 yr old with a BMI of ≥28 kg·m−2 and met PA safety requirements (i.e., no risk indicated by the Physical Activity Readiness Questionnaire [36] or clearance from a health care provider)." [2]
3. "Our results are provocative because we found that men who participated in the Hockey FIT program lost weight, increased their steps per day, and improved other clinical outcomes (e.g., systolic BP), their diet, and perceptions of their own health, to a greater extent compared with the controls." [3]

The full text provides clear information about the eligibility criteria for the trial. The participants were male fans of ice hockey teams in Ontario, aged 35-65 years, with a BMI of ≥28 kg·m−2. They also had to meet the physical activity safety requirements. The criteria are specific and do not exclude a large portion of the target population. Score: [4]

Recruitment:
1. "Recruitment of 80 eligible participants was completed in a short time frame using methods that were easy to implement and with no added costs." [4]
2. "Across both sites, the most successful methods of recruitment included communication from the hockey team via e-mail or social media (e.g., Twitter) and word of mouth, where 40% and 36% of men were recruited, respectively." [4]
3. "Although this study was designed as a pilot trial, we achieved many statistically and clinically important differences between groups at 12 wk, favoring the Hockey FIT group." [4]

The full text provides information about the recruitment methods used, including communication from the hockey team via e-mail or social media, word of mouth, traditional media sources, posters, and handouts. The recruitment was successful, with 80 eligible participants recruited in a short time frame. The methods used were easy to implement and did not require additional costs. Score: [4]

Setting:
1. "We conducted a pilot, pragmatic randomized controlled trial (pRCT; parallel groups, stratified by site) in Ontario, Canada." [2]
2. "We used a pragmatic approach for the program venue at each site, using a combination of the hockey team’s arena and an affiliated health club facility." [2]
3. "Although this study was designed as a pilot trial, we achieved many statistically and clinically important differences between groups at 12 wk, favoring the Hockey FIT group." [4]

The full text provides information about the setting of the trial, which took place in Ontario, Canada. The program venue was a combination of the hockey team's arena and an affiliated health club facility. The setting of the trial is similar to usual care, as it takes place in a real-world setting that is accessible to the target population. Score: [4]

Organisation:
1. "The Hockey FIT program was delivered over 12 weekly, 90-min sessions by Hockey FIT coaches (coach to participant ratio 2:20) from the central research team." [2]
2. "Participants were encouraged to continue with their lifestyle prescriptions and sustain their behavior changes with the support of free-of-charge eHealth tools." [2]
3. "Although this study was designed as a pilot trial, we achieved many statistically and clinically important differences between groups at 12 wk, favoring the Hockey FIT group." [4]

The full text provides information about the organization of care delivery in the intervention arm of the trial. The Hockey FIT program was delivered by trained coaches from the central research team. Participants were also provided with free eHealth tools to support their behavior changes. The organization of care delivery is similar to usual care, as it involves trained coaches and the use of technology to support participants. Score: [4]

2. "Participants were encouraged to continue with their lifestyle prescriptions and sustain their behavior changes with the support of free-of-charge eHealth tools." [2]
3. "Although this study was designed as a pilot trial, we achieved many statistically and clinically important differences between groups at 12 wk, favoring the Hockey FIT group." [4]

The full text does not provide enough information to assess the flexibility in how the intervention is delivered. Score: [NA]

1. "Participants were encouraged to continue with their lifestyle prescriptions and sustain their behavior changes with the support of free-of-charge eHealth tools." [2]
2. "Although this study was designed as a pilot trial, we achieved many statistically and clinically important differences between groups at 12 wk, favoring the Hockey FIT group." [4]

The full text does not provide enough information to assess the flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention. Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
1. "Trial retention was high at 12 wk (in both groups) and 12 months (intervention group only), and only one individual stated that he withdrew due to trial procedures (i.e., randomization)." [4]
2. "Furthermore, men were able to maintain most of these outcomes 12 months later, after a minimally supported phase, showing promise for long-term sustainability." [4]
3. "Although this study was designed as a pilot trial, we achieved many statistically and clinically important differences between groups at 12 wk, favoring the Hockey FIT group." [4]

The full text provides information about the follow-up of participants in the trial. Trial retention was high at 12 weeks and 12 months, with only one individual withdrawing due to trial procedures. The participants were able to maintain most of the outcomes 12 months later, indicating long-term sustainability. Score: [4]

Primary outcome:
1. "Our results are provocative because we found that men who participated in the Hockey FIT program lost weight, increased their steps per day, and improved other clinical outcomes (e.g., systolic BP), their diet, and perceptions of their own health, to a greater extent compared with the controls." [3]
2. "Furthermore, by 12 wk, 30% of men in the intervention group had achieved weight loss of 5% or more compared with only 3% of men in the comparator group." [3]
3. "Taken together, our findings suggest that we can achieve high retention rates and demonstrate the effectiveness of the Hockey FIT program in the planned definitive trial." [4]

The full text provides information about the primary outcome of the trial, which was weight loss. The participants in the intervention group lost more weight and achieved clinically significant weight loss of 5% or more compared to the comparator group. The results suggest that the trial's primary outcome is relevant to the participants. Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
1. "We analyzed outcome data to examine the potential effectiveness of the Hockey FIT program on the basis of an intent-to-treat approach." [4]
2. "We ran an additional linear mixed-effects model within the intervention group only to obtain exploratory estimates for mean change from baseline to 12 months." [4]
3. "Interpretation of results is primarily based on estimation and associated 95% confidence intervals (CIs)." [4]

The full text provides information about the primary analysis of the trial. The outcome data were analyzed using an intent-to-treat approach, and an additional analysis was conducted within the intervention group to obtain exploratory estimates for mean change from baseline to 12 months. The analysis included all available data and used estimation and confidence intervals for interpretation. Score: [5]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "We selected 156 pregnant women in their ≥ 37 week/s, who had cervical dilations of ≥ 4 cm and with two or more contractions in 10 minutes." [Quote 1]
2. "Those with the following were excluded: serious preeclampsia, placenta previa, immediate indication of cesarean, dilations at ≥ 8 cm and those that used analgesics for less than six hours from the study admission time." [Quote 2]
3. "The size of the sample was estimated through considering the proposed calculation method for the non-paired 14 t test." [Quote 3]

The study clearly defines the eligibility criteria for the participants, including gestational age, cervical dilation, and contractions. It also excludes participants with specific conditions or indications for cesarean section. The sample size calculation is mentioned, indicating that the study aimed to recruit an adequate number of participants. Overall, the study appears to have a pragmatic approach to eligibility criteria.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:
1. "The pregnant women were randomly divided into three groups at a university hospital in the suburbs of Sao Paulo, Brazil, in order to receive either acupressure treatment, a placebo or participate as part of a control group." [Quote 1]
2. "The study used the single-blind method (participants in the SP6 and TG groups did not know what group they were in)." [Quote 2]

The study recruited participants from a university hospital in Sao Paulo, Brazil. It employed randomization to allocate participants to different groups, including an acupressure treatment group, a placebo group, and a control group. The use of single-blind method suggests that efforts were made to minimize bias in participant recruitment. However, the full text does not provide information on the specific recruitment strategies used, such as targeted invitation letters or advertising, which would be more indicative of a pragmatic approach.

Score: [3]

Setting:
1. "We undertook a controlled and randomized clinical test (based on the consort diagram) employing the use of pragmatism. It was carried out between January and August of 2013. The subjects were pregnant women admitted to a teaching tertiary public hospital on the outskirts of the state of Sao Paulo, Brazil." [Quote 1]

The study was conducted in a teaching tertiary public hospital in Sao Paulo, Brazil. The use of a hospital setting suggests that the study may have a more explanatory approach, as it may not represent the usual care setting for pregnant women in labor. However, the full text does not provide information on whether the hospital setting was similar to usual care settings in terms of resources and expertise, making it difficult to fully assess the domain.

Score: [NA]

Organisation:
1. "The researcher that was responsible for applying the acupressure went through 32 hours' worth of training." [Quote 1]
2. "The pregnant women in labor obtained normal obstetrical treatment. Where the study was carried out, the following was permitted: the presence of someone to accompany the pregnant lady, the use of methods other than drugs such as taking a shower, massages in the lower back region and breathing exercises as well as liberty of movement (in cases where this did not go against medical advice)." [Quote 2]

The researcher responsible for applying the acupressure received training, indicating that additional expertise was required for the intervention. However, the study states that the pregnant women received normal obstetrical treatment, including the use of non-drug methods for pain relief and freedom of movement. This suggests that the organization of care delivery in the intervention arm was similar to usual care. Overall, the study appears to have a pragmatic approach to organization.

Score: [4]

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "The SP6 group with the pregnant women in labor received deep pressure (± 5kg) with fast decompression applied to their thumbs which did not bring about any discomfort." [Quote 1]

The study describes the specific protocol for delivering the acupressure intervention, including the amount of pressure applied. The protocol appears to be relatively strict, with specific instructions on the pressure and technique. This suggests a more explanatory approach, as there is a strict protocol for delivering the intervention.

Score: [2]

Flexibility (adherence):
Score: [NA]

Follow-up:
1. "VAS was used to evaluate the pain and for pre-developed questions. The women were able to classify their perception of the pain." [Quote 1]

The study used the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) to measure pain and collected data at multiple time points. The use of VAS suggests that the intensity of measurement and follow-up were more intensive than usual care. However, the full text does not provide information on the frequency or duration of follow-up visits, making it difficult to fully assess the domain.

Score: [NA]

Primary outcome:
1. "The averages for the pain measured using the VAS were not different for the three groups that were a part of the study (p-value=0.0929), however they were less in the acupressure groups immediately after receiving the treatment (p-value=<0.0001)." [Quote 1]

The study evaluated the primary outcome of pain using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). The outcome of pain is relevant to the participants and is directly measured. The study found a significant difference in pain immediately after receiving the acupressure treatment. Overall, the study appears to have a pragmatic approach to the primary outcome.

Score: [4]

Primary analysis:
1. "The Kruskal-Wallis test was used to make comparisons between the groups in relation to quantitative variables. The Mann-Whitney test was used in cases where significant differences were found for multiple comparisons." [Quote 1]

The study used appropriate statistical tests, such as the Kruskal-Wallis test and the Mann-Whitney test, to analyze the primary outcome data. The use of intention-to-treat analysis and inclusion of all available data is not explicitly mentioned in the full text. However, the study does not mention any exclusions based on eligibility post-randomization or inclusion of only completers or those following the treatment protocol. Overall, the study appears to have a pragmatic approach to the primary analysis.

Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Excluded were individuals who had another major disease (among them individuals with asthma who had more than 200 ml or 12% increase in FEV1 after inhalation of 200 μg albuterol in the post-bronchodilator spirometry), who were non-Icelandic speaking, not capable of travelling to the treatment site and those who had participated in a structured rehabilitation programme for people with COPD 6 months prior to the screening." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Recruitment:
1. "All potentially relevant patients (n = 291) were contacted for enrolment in the study from primary healthcare settings (n = 8) and the offices of private lung physicians (n = 6) in the Reykjavik capital area of Iceland." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>
2. "There were 119 patients who started participation, with 100 completing the study." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Setting:
1. "The treatment site was a clinical research centre located on a university-hospital campus." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [3]</moved-squared-brackets>

Organisation:
1. "The intervention was an addition to traditional health care which the control group received. Traditional health care refers to services provided by general practitioners at primary health care centres and visits to lung physicians based on referral from general practitioners or self-initiated appointments." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "The theoretical framework, Partnership with people with COPD and their families, was the basis for this intervention. It was adjusted to the particular needs of young people with COPD in its early stages." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary outcome:
1. "The 6-month partnership-based self-management programme had benefits on the perception of the intrusiveness of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and its treatment on lifestyles, activities and interests for young patients with the disease in its early stages." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "From their computerised asthma registers the practices identified adults (⩾18 years) who had asked for a bronchodilator inhaler prescription in the previous six months but who had not had a routine asthma review in the preceding 11 months." [Quote 1]
2. "Patients were excluded if the diagnosis of asthma had been made within the previous year, if they had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, if communication difficulties made a telephone consultation impossible, or (at the general practitioner's request) for major social or medical reasons." [Quote 2]

The eligibility criteria for this trial appear to be relatively pragmatic. The inclusion criteria are broad, including adults who had asked for a bronchodilator inhaler prescription in the previous six months but had not had a routine asthma review in the preceding 11 months. The exclusion criteria are also reasonable, excluding patients with recent asthma diagnosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, communication difficulties, or major social or medical reasons. Overall, the trial seems to have a pragmatic approach to participant eligibility.

Score: [4]

Recruitment:
1. "Patients were randomised to the telephone review group were sent a letter from their practice informing them that they had been allocated to receive a telephone review and that they should expect a call from the asthma nurse within a month." [Quote 3]
2. "Patients randomised to the face to face consultation arm were sent a written invitation to make an appointment to see the asthma nurse within a month." [Quote 4]

The recruitment process for this trial appears to be relatively pragmatic. Patients were allocated to either the telephone review group or the face to face consultation group and were informed of their allocation through letters or invitations. The methods used for recruitment are similar to what would be used in usual care settings, making it a pragmatic approach.

Score: [4]

Setting:
1. "Four general practices in England." [Quote 5]

The trial was conducted in four general practices in England. While the number of practices is limited, they are representative of usual care settings. Therefore, the setting of the trial can be considered relatively pragmatic.

Score: [4]

Organisation:

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "The inclusion criteria were: a positive diagnosis of RA (1987 American College of Rheumatology (ACR) criteria),29 age 18 years or older and the ability to complete questionnaires unaided. Exclusions were: unstabilised concomitant disease, awaiting surgery and already receiving care from the practitioners involved in the study." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Recruitment:
1. "The study was conducted in outpatient clinics of 10 rheumatology centres across the UK." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Setting:
1. "The study was conducted in outpatient clinics of 10 rheumatology centres across the UK." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Organisation:
1. "This study required three practitioners at each centre; a CNS, a rheumatologist and a blind independent assessor. Nine CNS and 10 rheumatologists delivered the interventions. The CNS had a median experience of 10 years in their current post while the rheumatologists had a median of 9 years at consultant level." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "The NLC interventions usually include allocated 30-min time slots in which the CNS takes history, performs physical examination, pain control, prescribing or recommending medication and dosage changes, intra-articular or intramuscular steroid injections, provision of patient education, psychosocial support and ordering blood tests or X-rays." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [3]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (adherence):
1. "NLC has lower consultation costs." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Follow-up:
1. "Patients were seen by their respective practitioners at baseline and at weeks 13, 26, 39 and 52." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary outcome:
1. "The primary outcome was the disease activity score (DAS28) assessed at baseline, weeks 13, 26, 39 and 52; the non-inferiority margin being DAS28 change of 0.6." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary analysis:
1. "Analysis followed per-protocol (PP) and intention-to-treat (ITT) approaches." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Overall Score: [4]

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Men and women aged ≥18 years at high CVD risk, defined as either established CVD (history of coronary, ischaemic cerebrovascular, or peripheral vascular disease) or an estimated five-year CVD risk of ≥15% (using the Framingham risk equation, including a 5% increment for Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander identification)21 were eligible." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Recruitment:
2. "Participants were excluded if it was felt clinically inappropriate to alter medications." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Setting:
3. "All participants were treated by their regular doctor following randomization." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Organisation:
4. "The Kanyini GAP trial was designed to be highly pragmatic with the prescribing, dispensing and payment for polypill occurring identically to what would be usual care, if the polypill were to be marketed in Australia and subsidized through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (delivery):
5. "No attempt was made to influence any other aspect of their management. The doctor could, at any time, change prescription to the alternative polypill version, add drugs on top of the polypill, or withdraw the polypill and substitute individual drugs of their choice." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (adherence):
6. "The adherence outcome was a composite of adherence to all three treatment modalities, but there were smaller adherence improvements for each individual treatment modality." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Follow-up:
7. "Participants attended the primary healthcare centres for trial assessments at randomization and 12 month intervals thereafter." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary outcome:
8. "Primary outcomes were self-reported use of indicated combination treatment (antiplatelet, statin and ≥2 BP lowering therapies for ≥4 of the previous seven days) at study end; and changes in systolic BP and total cholesterol from baseline to study end." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

Primary analysis:
9. "All analyses were conducted on an intention-to-treat basis without imputation of missing data." <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Patients were followed up for 2 years (up to April 2013) and 215 had complete follow-up data." - This quote indicates that the trial followed patients for a relatively long period of time, which suggests that the eligibility criteria were pragmatic and allowed for inclusion of patients who would typically be followed up in usual care. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Recruitment:
1. "The PROFHER collaborators recruited patients for this pragmatic, open, multicenter, parallel-group, superiority, randomized clinical trial between September 2008 and April 2011 from orthopedic departments (fracture clinics or wards) at 32 acute UK National Health Service hospitals." - This quote suggests that the trial recruited patients from usual care settings, such as orthopedic departments in hospitals, which indicates a pragmatic approach to recruitment. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Setting:
1. "The PROFHER collaborators recruited patients for this pragmatic, open, multicenter, parallel-group, superiority, randomized clinical trial between September 2008 and April 2011 from orthopedic departments (fracture clinics or wards) at 32 acute UK National Health Service hospitals." - This quote indicates that the trial was conducted in multiple centers, including acute UK National Health Service hospitals, which suggests a pragmatic approach to the setting. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Organisation:
1. "It was emphasized that good standards of care, both surgical and nonsurgical, should be provided throughout the treatment pathway for the injury, including surgical care or management of the sling, postoperative care, and rehabilitation in both groups." - This quote suggests that the trial aimed to provide care that is consistent with usual care standards, indicating a pragmatic approach to organization. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "It was emphasized that good standards of care, both surgical and nonsurgical, should be provided throughout the treatment pathway for the injury, including surgical care or management of the sling, postoperative care, and rehabilitation in both groups." - This quote suggests that the trial aimed to provide care that is consistent with usual care standards, indicating a pragmatic approach to the delivery of the intervention. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [4]</moved-squared-brackets>

Flexibility (adherence):
1. "Participating hospitals did not introduce new or experimental interventions for these fractures during the study." - This quote suggests that there were no specific measures to improve adherence to the intervention, indicating a more explanatory approach. Primary outcome:
1. "The primary outcome was the Oxford Shoulder Score (range, 0-48; higher scores indicate better outcomes) assessed during a 2-year period, with assessment and data collection at 6, 12, and 24 months." - This quote indicates that the primary outcome was patient-reported and relevant to participants, as it assessed their shoulder function. <moved-squared-brackets>Score: [5]</moved-squared-brackets>

llm_message:
Eligibility:
1. "Patients were eligible to participate if they were: community dwelling aged ≥65 years; independently mobile (with or without a walking aid); and physically able to take part in group exercise." [1]
2. "Patients were excluded if they: had experienced ≥3 falls in the previous year; had unstable clinical conditions; would be unable to follow instructions about exercise safely; or were receiving palliative care." [1]

The eligibility criteria for this trial seem to be quite pragmatic, as they include a broad range of older people who are community dwelling and able to participate in group exercise. There are some exclusions based on falls history and clinical conditions, but these are reasonable and necessary for participant safety. Score: [4]

Recruitment:
1. "Practices were recruited with assistance from Primary Care Research Networks for London, Derby, and Nottingham. Patients aged ≥65 years were identified by searches of computerised medical records and invited to participate by letter from their GP." [1]

The recruitment process for this trial seems to be quite pragmatic, as it involves identifying eligible patients from primary care records and inviting them to participate through their GP. This is a common and feasible approach that would be used in usual care. Score: [5]

Setting:
1. "Pragmatic three-arm, parallel-design cluster randomised controlled trial involving 1256 people aged ≥65 years (of 20 507 invited) recruited from 43 general practices in London, Nottingham, and Derby." [1]

The trial was conducted in general practices in London, Nottingham, and Derby, which are typical settings for primary care in the UK. This is a pragmatic choice that reflects the usual care setting. Score: [5]

Organisation:
1. "The interventions were the home-based Otago Exercise Programme (OEP), and a group-based exercise programme called Falls Management Exercise (FaME)." [1]
2. "Volunteer peer mentors supported participants in the OEP arm, and weekly FaME classes were run in local venues by postural stability instructors trained to work with older people." [1]

The organization of care delivery in this trial seems to be quite pragmatic. The interventions were delivered by trained instructors and peer mentors, which is feasible in usual care. There is no indication of additional resources or staff levels being required. Score: [5]

Flexibility (delivery):
1. "The interventions were the home-based Otago Exercise Programme (OEP), and a group-based exercise programme called Falls Management Exercise (FaME)." [1]
2. "The programmes included the following progression: OEP — ankle weights and hand holds; and FaME — resistance bands and hand holds, plus a move to more dynamic balance work and floor work with postural stability instructors." [1]

The flexibility in how the interventions were delivered seems to be quite pragmatic. The OEP was home-based and the FaME program included both group-based and home-based components. The progression of exercises also reflects a pragmatic approach, as it allows for individualization and adaptation based on participant capabilities. Score: [4]

Flexibility (adherence):
1. "Adherence was defined as (minutes spent exercising/intended minutes) 100%, where patients with values exceeding 75% were regarded as ‘adherent’." [1]

The flexibility in how participants must adhere to the intervention seems to be quite pragmatic. Adherence was defined as a percentage of intended minutes, with a threshold of 75% considered as adherent. This allows for some flexibility and recognizes that not all participants may be able to adhere to the intervention 100% of the time. Score: [5]

Follow-up:
1. "Participants were followed up every 6 months after the end of the intervention period, until 24 months." [1]

The intensity of measurement and follow-up in this trial seems to be quite pragmatic. Participants were followed up every 6 months for a total of 24 months, which is a reasonable and feasible approach in usual care. Score: [5]

Primary outcome:
1. "The primary outcome was the proportion of participants who reported reaching ≥150 minutes of MVPA per week." [1]

The primary outcome of this trial seems to be quite pragmatic, as it focuses on a measure of physical activity that is relevant and meaningful to participants. Score: [5]

Primary analysis:
1. "Participants were analysed in the groups to which they were randomised, regardless of whether they received the intervention or not, and multiple imputation was used to include all participants in the analyses." [1]

The primary analysis of this trial seems to be quite pragmatic, as it includes all participants in the analysis regardless of their adherence to the intervention. Multiple imputation was also used to account for missing data, which is a pragmatic approach to handling missing data. Score: [5]
